pros: Loved my patients. Loved the team work among my team coworkers
cons: Too many hours, too many patients. Worked 12-16+ hrs M - F. review_title: Lack of respect for professionalism of staff, Serious Management Problems Create Bad Morale
pros: I was working with awesome nurses, social workers, CNA's in the field. Of course, serving patients and families at the end of life is a privilege.
cons:
Managers attempt to rule according to their financial restrictions and shortsighted needs. Managers seem to not know the mission of hospice service.

review_title: The fish rots from the head
pros: Ability to serve patients and families at end of life
cons: Being lead by a CEO and President that lack empathy and are only concerned about admissions, billing and gathering donations from ill-informed donors. This Hospice is 180 degrees from what it used to be.

pros:
Mission Moments - I love hearing how staff have gone the extra mile to bring 'More from Life" as we tailor care to individual needs.
Specialized Programs - I am so grateful that I work for a non-profit company that continually invests in an abundance of supportive programs that include support for our Veterans, Pediatrics, Footprints, and many more. 
I have personally had several family and friends who have been cared for by The Denver Hospice. Sitting with a loved one in the tranquil garden, seeing their memory stone engraved with their name, and having the continued support to cope with loss are just a few of the many reasons why I've made The Denver Hospice a lifelong career opportunity. I hope you do too.
cons: There can be a day here or there of high emotion when you've worked really hard to bring a patient to a level of comfort, only to lose them shortly after. It's our hospice heart they say that allows us to continue to be a part of bringing peace and dignity to an individual's journeys end.

pros: Rewarding work with the dying
cons: Unreasonable caseloads, high turnover, employees worked to the bone

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Denver, CO
pros:
I have been a nurse for over 20 years. Have never worked for a company that truly lives it's mission. They allow people to fulfill their dying wish, they care for newborns to people 100+. They have the highest caliber staff and take the most complex people. They also play fair and don't belittle other companies---just do what is needed to care for patients. 
They care for their employees. They get berated for doing what is right ethically and never lash out to those stating otherwise.
cons: Currently on the recieving line of a lot of community backlash from previous employees who left for 'more money', 'greener pastures', etc and who are finding it isn't so and that the quality care isn't there so they are really bashing The Denver Hospice. Always question where the bad info is coming from and what is truly driving it.

review_title: I love my job at The Denver Hospice
job_title: Registered Nurse Manager in Denver, CO
pros: The mission, if your desire is to work for a not-for-profit doing important work (caring for patients and their families during a difficult time) The Denver Hospice is a great place to bring your talent. I have only been with the company for six months but have had a very long career in healthcare and this is the best company I have worked with. People work at The Denver Hospice because they have a passion for the work. Leadership is open with communication, available to everyone and in my experience can be trusted. Melinda Egging, CEO know employees at all levels by name. While the work is demanding, when you go home, you feel good about what you did that day.
cons: I am having a hard time coming up with a con.

pros: Amazing field staff who are dedicated to excellent patient care. Hospice work takes special people, it’s sacred work and frontline staff heart’s are in the right place. If you work out in the field, you aren’t exposed to the toxic management of this company.
cons: Staff are not valued by upper management-anyone is expendable.The President & CEO make unbelievable salaries while they cut pay, benefits and staffing for frontline caregivers. They are rude to employees and have created a very negative and toxic culture. Patient care is no longer a priority-everyone is expected to do more with less. RN caseloads are very high-way above industry standards. Staff have to work a lot of time that is uncompensated because they are paid by salary. Management does not value feedback or input from staff, that is why the employees made an effort to unionize. Changes are made that negatively impact patient care without any input. Upper management is mostly new. Lots of good staff are leaving by the day.....

review_title: The Denver Hospice the biggest, but not the best
pros: The majority of the employees are good hearted well intentioned folks - The work is of the heart
cons:
VERY CORPORATE, NO HONEST COMMUNICATION FROM TOP DOWN
Over paid CEO (care synergy) for a "non profit",  No caring about employees they are considered resources to be plugged into needed holes in the schedule and become a cog in the machine - no real innovation in hospice care and more focused on appeasing facility clients than providing best care across the board to home care and facility patients

review_title: Listen to the advice and run
pros: The insanely loving and caring nurses that dwindle in number as the days progress.
cons: Management's failures worsens patient care.

job_title: Clinical Operations Associate in Denver, CO
pros: I have been part of the incredible TDH Team for almost 6 years  - sacred mission and values, LOVE the senior management , LOVE the professional nurses, CNAs, Chaplains, and Social Workers. The staff is passionate about providing optimal care for patients at home, facilities, and in the inpatient care center. I have never worked with so many dedicated people who do their Best each and every day to serve out patients, families, caregivers, and others.  We are a U.S. leader in not-for-profit hospices and so appreciate community donations to provide the BEST care possible.
cons: No cons to report as all continues to go well - very successful model company.

review_title: I love this company, the majority of employees, management, and the people we serve
pros:
The many different kinds of employees in ALL the various roles, from CNAs, COAs, nurses, social workers, chaplains, clinical managers, office administration, human resources, executives, and leadership.  The MAJORITY of them are straight good people with good hearts who chose this industry to make a difference, and they do.

Of course, the patients, their families, and loved ones.  It is such a hard time for them and I choose like the many others at the the Denver Hospice to be there for them 100% no different than I am for fellow employees, to include management, and vice versa.
cons: The Denver Hospice takes care of all of their employees.  We are all paid very well on all of the various different levels in comparison to other companies, and we are given flexibility.  They are the best non-profit that I have EVER worked for.  This is truth from my own current and previous experiences.   Unfortunately there are always deceptive and manipulating employees though also which is no different than what any other industry or business has, whether it's a non-profit or for profit company.  These employees are always angry.  They seek to continually disrupt and try to maximize their own standings for their own gain (a different kind of greed) even if it is at the expense of the structure, finances, company, and everyone else inside.  They are never happy and are straight jealous if others who have additionally sacrificed for not a day, week, month, or year.......but yearssssss, continue to do what they do, work hard, similarly balance everything else out in life, and go on to graduate college in the many different disciplines, or are simply promoted for their hard work over themselves.  For some reason these negative employees  feel like they should be entitled to be bosses or  paid more than others simply for not going the extra mile in and outside of work  like others have done.  Their entitlement makes them feel as if showing up to work fairly consistently and carrying out their duties (which is expected of anyone anyhow) should be rewarded over others who have simply done more.  It's disgusting.  Those employees are the ones who make a toxic work environment.  They gossip, hate, stir up the pot, and make others outside of their own miserable little circles uncomfortable, even if they are on the same level.  Why should anyone decide to work hard at anything inside or outside of their job, go on to actually finish college (which has Bachelors, Masters, PhDs), get licensed in a trade that is equivalent to time, structure, and money, or sacrifice for the entire country by joining the military which has it's own structure/ranks?  Obviously weasely employees feel like they should just be given things or everyone should suffer their wrath.  Give me a break.

review_title: Unethical? could be....  Lacking integrity?  For sure
pros: End of life care and caring teams
cons: Lost non-profit focus. No one can operate in the red, but the TDH CEO and President have pushed the bottom line up to a two digit percentage point. CEO and President keep getting more money and bonuses for management. Shameful

review_title: The people are great, the agency...not so much.
pros: The pay is fair. They offer insurance and PTO. The hours can be flexible, depending on the department you wok in. The people are friendly.
cons: Always get a sense that the agency is trying too hard and making changes without thinking them through completely. Then, the employees pay...layoffs are always looming. Then, they have the nerve to ask for donations and invite you to events that you can't afford.

pros: Rewarding work (but you can get this elsewhere), okay benefits
cons: It is clearly heading for bankruptcy. People don’t work as a team. Pay is well below market and they only give raises yearly that are laughably low all the while hiring another unnecessary VP. No work life balance. They used to really care about the patients but that is simply not the case anymore as they ask us to do unethical things (i.e. not saying anything when patients are being neglected). They are already facing lawsuits from former employees so please save your time and work somewhere else.

review_title: being a large agency has its pros and cons
